p.future: I believe the relationship, personally, wouldn't progress much further beyond this point. I would be extremely interested in the reasoning behind my partner's actions, but the actions do speak for themselves. I would not wish to continue in a realtionship with someone who has cheated on me, but I would be willing to listen. Depending on the seriousness of the relationship, I woukld have to carefully consider all factors. Ultimately, however, I am not very forgiving with regards to cheating, so the relationship would probably end at that point.

p.future: I believe my relationship will definitely suffer, if not end. It is unacceptable to cheat in that context especially with one of my close friends. Not only would my friend lose his friendship my girlfriend would be no longer viable. With another person it is more understandable, but with a friend it is unacceptable. To imagine a future with her would be impossible as the situation is very likely to occur again as most likely she will still be in contact with that friend and be near him so the option would be there for her to do it again. There would be no way for it to continue.

p.future: I think that this incident would certainly cause a serious strain in our relationship and would make me ask a lot of questions and reevaluate a lot about our relationship moving forward (if we even moved forward with our relationship). I think the main issue that would be almost impossible to overcome would be the violation of trust that occurred. Since my girlfriend and I have been dating for a while (over a year), we do a lot together but do a lot with other people as well, and before this incident occurred I trusted her completely. But because this incident occurred, in the future I will probably become suspicious all the time of what she is doing and whether she is cheating on me again. For this reason, I think it would be very difficult to continue on with the relationship without it being very different. The only reason I would want to continue with the relationship is because I do love her, but if she doesn't love me and would rather sleep with other guys, I don't think there would be any reason for our relationship to develop in the future.
fq1: This study was easy to follow and move through, and the directions were clear.
fq3: I thought it was interesting that the majority of the study focused on imagining an incident of cheating occurring (i.e. something that would harm the relationship) rather than focusing on the strengths of the relationship.
fq4: I think that this study was focused on finding possible relationships between a person's reaction to an incident of cheating and various characteristics of the person, i.e. strength of the relationship, their general attitudes toward life, their current mood, their reaction to depressing situations, etc.

p.future: We wouldn't be able to go on.  Our relationship is based off of communication and trust, and cheating violates those principles at the highest level.  I suppose after I took a few weeks to cool down I would get more information to see what happened, then gauge what I should do.  Because my feelings are so strong, I would probably be willing to forgive, but not forget, and not for a while, three or four months at least.  After that if we are together at all, the relationship would be rocky because our foundation of trust would no longer be solid.

p.future: The person that I am, how I have been raised, and how seriosuly I take being in relationships, this would end the relationship.  I do not believe in entering in relationships if you are not fully committed, especially at this point in my life.  I have said to my partner that if he ever felt mildly inclined to be unfaithful to me, to just break up with me and it would be so much easier on both of us - there would be no guilt, just pain; there would be no betrayl; just sadness.  This is tollerable.  I would not -- and have not in the past -- entered into a relationship while I was unsure if that is where I wanted to be.  If my mind wandered, I'd end it.  No matter how much I love my partner, and how hard i know it would be to end it, I would.  It's like ripping off a bandaid. And i'm not saying this because I don't actually love my partner or its not a very serious relationship or whatever, i'm saying this because I would, in this situation, put my pride above my personal feelings.  That's the type of person I am, good or bad.

p.future: I would definitely go about my relationship in a more skeptical way if I did end up staying with my boyfriend after he cheated on me.  There would not be as much trust between us, and it would take me a while to feel as comfortable with him as I did before.  I would question why he was unfaithful, thinking of what I may have done to inspire this.  But on the other hand, I would have to find out what was going through his mind when he cheated.  Was he drunk?  Was he drugged?  Was he thinking that I would never find out?  Did he need to rebel in order to be completely satisfied with our relationship?  There are many questions that would race through my mind, and I would have to reassure myself that it had nothing to do with him wanting to get with a prettier/wealthier/better girl than I am.

p.future: I was already raised by a mother who's first husband cheated on her. So, growing up, I learned that once someone cheats on you, that's it, they're done, you're done, your relationship is finished. It is not worth being with someone whom you can't trust. When my boyfriend of 1 year and I started dating, it was a little abstract. We had been friends since freshman year of highschool (I am now a Junior in college) and we even "dated" a little bit freshman year. So we decided to just be "friends with benefits". This was a great fit for me because I didn't want a boyfriend and he had just gotten out of a long one. While we were still "no strings attached", he made out with another girl on a dance floor. I was pissed, but I knew I didn't have a right to be angyry because we had an agreement. When he told me of this he said that he hated how it felt and he only wanted to be with me. While I know the saying "once a cheater, always a cheater", I do not think that my boyfriend will ever cheat on me. He is an extremely trust worthy individual in all aspects of his life. Writing this out has really made me feel silly for ever questioning our "strings attached" relationship that occured after we decided that we didn't want each other seeing other people. Last summer he had an intership in another state and I went to visit him twice. Of course, a paranoid person like me wondered if he ever cheated, however, there were no grounds, and I completely see that now. This incident has actually made me realize how strong our relationship is.
fq1: At first it made me feel sad thinking about it a situation like that. But then I felt angry and almost defensive about my relationship because we would never cheat on each other.
fq2: After I imagined the situation, there were some unclear questions.
fq3: The questions were repetitive- but most psych studies have repetitive questions. I also had to keep my headphones on the entire time, so maybe there was some subliminal messaging going on.
fq4: How something as simple as imagining a scenario make people angry. How secure people feel in their relationships.

p.future: If this incident were to occur in my relationship it would be over. I highly doubt there would be any sort of a relationship thereafter, I would choose to ignore him and the other woman and remove all contact with both people.

p.future: Trust would be completely gone.  If he really was determined to stay in the relationship and I was somehow able to accept what happened as the past, the dynamics of our relationship would be completely different.  He would have to work hard to regain my trust and I would have to work hard to allow myself to trust him again.  I would have to try not to be bitter but I would make it clear that this was NOT acceptable.

p.future: After this incident I am very certain that there will be trust issue if my partner and I were to compromise and continue the relationship. I wouldn't feel comfortable with my partner being around my close friends or any other female in general. I would think that he has intentions on having sexual intercourse with them. I would want to be informed about his where abouts more frequently, and would want to spend more time with him, just to make sure he isn't doing anything he shouldn't. I would also ask my partner was I a factor in the reason why he cheated. If so, can there be ways in which I could change some of my ways for the betterment of our relationship. I would also explain the problems that I have with him, and would hope he would change them accordingly, again, for the betterment of our relationship.  If we weren't able to continue our relationship, it would be difficult for me to engage in another relationship with someone else, because I feel that this situation could happen again.

p.future: I think we would put some distance between us romantically. We could try to be friends, and maybe after a while we would be together again. It wouldn't happen very quickly though. It would always feel kind of funny to talk with each other about other people we'd see. There would be less trust, probably in a cyclical way. It might end up being self-destructive.

p.future: At first, I would feel betrayed. Like I'd been punched in the stomach.  I'd want to know everything about what happened (where, when, how long, why, etc.).  I would feel angry and wouldn't want my partner to leave because I would want to berate him.  I know that when he did leave I would feel such sadness.  I think I would mostly be angry at him.  I would also be angry with my friend, but more him.  Jealous perhaps.  I'm pretty sure I would break it off with him.  I don't believe I would ever be able to trust him again.  His explanations would never be enough.  Even if he said that it was a drunken incident, perhaps because my friend was attractive, it would also seem like more.  Like he must've been thinking about it before it happened and must be thinking about it after.  I would know that he always shared this incidence with my friend and I believe that's why I wouldn't be able to get over it.  That no matter what happened between us, he would be able to flash back to that moment.  Maybe to compare us, or maybe just an flashback to that night.  Maybe it's because I believe that sex can never be just sex.  What if she was sad and needed comforting, would he be willing to text her back?  I would break up with him and then try to stay strong, but it would be a break-up so I know the loneliness would hurt me.  At this point in my relationship, I know my boyfriend would be beside himself and be trying to get me back.  That would make me feel good so I can honestly not say if I would let him back in.  If I remained strong and didnt' get back together with him, I would know I made the right decision once the pain subsided.  If I broke down and allowed us to date again I don't know if things would every be the same.  I'd always be angry when I was around him.  I think it would take at least a year (if we lasted that long) for the angry to subside and hopefully the trust to return.
